comment._content: Are the bits of wood and broken gearwheel in the foreground remnants of a 'boat found at sea'? (So maybe it wasn't the Sarah McDonald that was found at sea)!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: If the Sarah MacDonald was found at sea, it was presumably damaged and abandoned. The finders would have to make some repairs in order to sail her to Waterford, and the broken bits and pieces, ladders and frayed ropes may be left over from repairs at sea.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Stupidly, only just now checked the other photo Niall pointed out earlier, and at high res the name is clearly visible - it's definitely Sarah McDonald.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Freeman's of July 25 1877 lists in the Shipping Lists a Sarah MacDonald sailing for Dublin from London Customs House

June 14th 1880: "The Perseverence, from Buenos Aires, and the Sarah MacDonald, from Warrington, were in collision on Friday evening in the Mersey. The latter sustained considerable damage."

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: They definitely didn't find that broken metal cogwheel floating in the ocean!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: "Boat found at sea" is so delightfully Irish.  In a "Dog bites Man" kind of way ...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: August 25, 1895 (Glasgow Herald): "A telegram from Northfleet, August 24, states: the schooner Sarah MacDonald, of Chester, from Northfleet to Limerick, with cement, in getting under weigh, fouled the ship Sierra Pedrosa, loading at buoy off Northfleet, doing damage to midship rail, also damaged gear of barge Jay, which was loading alongside ship."

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
This website Wrecks of Pembrokeshire has the following entry for 1911
October 7th. SARAH MACDONALD. Schooner. Off Smalls Ran aground sails fully set, re-floated herself and sank. Cargo of China Clay.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I've found it in the Freeman's Journal! Back in a mo...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: From page 5 of the Freeman's Journal on Wednesday, 15 October 1913: "Derelict Schooner off Irish Coast [Photo is the "other" one in our Poole Collection that Niall referenced earlier] In the recent heavy gales the schooner "Sarah MacDonald" of Chester, carrying a cargo of china clay, was abandoned by her crew and was picked up later by the steam trawler "Neptune" of Ostend, who towed her to Waterford Harbour, where our photograph shows her."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The Wrecks of Pembrokeshire website says that many of the wrecks are still undiscovered. In the case of the Sarah MacDonald, it's not surprising!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
London Times Oct 8 1913
St Davids, Oct 7th - British schooner Sarah MacDonald, for Runcorn, china clay, struck S W rock today. Crew left in their own boats and landed at lighthouse. Schooner drifted away

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Could this be her final resting place? If it is the same Sarah MacDonald, much more here: www.friendsofpurton.org.uk/Phase_One/Sarah_Macdonald_Phas...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So this unlucky schooner was indeed "found at sea"! Thank you everyone, great to have solved the mystery and to be able to add a "Date Established" tag. I've left it vague at October 1913... Can we better tie it down, if you'll pardon the pun? Between drifting on 7 October, and photograph in Freeman's Journal that can't be any later than 14 October (day before it was printed in newspaper)?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: These men are perhaps crew from the Neptune which was a steam trawler and may explain why they look like boilermen. The Neptune was sunk by German submarine UC-46 in 1916. Fortunately for our friends here, there were no casualties: This Belgium trawler was stopped by a German submarine, her crew forced to abandon ship, after which she was sunk, but whether by explosive scuttling charges or gun fire is not known.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 26 December 1916: 0.126 "NEPTUNE": door een vijandelijke U-boot getorpedeerd. Bemanning: Zonnekeyn Louis, schipper. Aspeslagh Jacques, stuurman. Corveleyn Victor, Labbeke Eugeen, Vanacker Charles en Vanacker Leon, matrozen. Vansieleghem Louis, machinist. Torreborre Vincent en Depaep Leon, stokers

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So the Neptune was sunk 'near Smalls' and the Sarah MacDonald hit rocks 'off Smalls'. Is this a coincidence, or are the Smalls so remote that the phrase 'nears Smalls' covers a large area, and it's the area where the Neptune would habitually spend a large time harvesting the sea? Satellite view (no streets in view but there is a lighthouse) OS Map of the Smalls:

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] I don't think it's a coincidence, the only boat likely to find an abandoned ship drifting is a boat that is usually in those waters. Apparently the Neptune was still fishing those waters in 1916.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
The place to find the definitive answer to this will be LLoyds List where all maritime accidents etc are recorded. Abandoning a ship at sea has great consequences for the owners, since under the maritime law of salvage the vessel becomes the property of whoever puts the "first line" aboard when the vessel is being recovered and ceases to be the property of the original owners. The new owner can then do what he likes with cargo and vessel. I am not sure whether the records for this incident are online or held at Lloyds on microfilm.

Given what has been highlighted here, the name "Sarah Mc Donald" is right up there with Princess Victoria and Titanic for "names not to call a ship"!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Somewhat bizarrely (and completely off subject), a Sarah Mc Donald from Getty Images(!) has just appeared on The One Show talking about old photos!
